name: kunthar
text: it seems, we need to create steps of development stage. It means CI&CD should be transferred to community monitored alternative. We are using Buildbot in house, but i think Travis CI would be a good candidate. Anyone knows a good tool chain for github->CI&CD->builds would be cool.

name: peterclark
text: Travis CI is free for open source projects, so that would be handy.

name: kunthar
text: we as Zetaops, can provide one server located in Germany, Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-6700 CPU @ 3.40GHz with 65GB RAM. Two public ips, ~115GB Storage.

attachments.fallback: Private Maven, RPM, DEB, PyPi and RubyGem Repository | packagecloud
attachments.text: Free hosted Debian, RPM, Java, Python and RubyGem repositories. Chef, Puppet, Jenkins, Buildkite, CircleCI and Travis CI integrations.
attachments.title: Private Maven, RPM, DEB, PyPi and RubyGem Repository | packagecloud

name: kunthar
text: and AFAIK <https://packagecloud.io/> provides free hosting for open source projects

name: peterclark
text: They do - 25Gb storage, and 250GB of bandwidth. Needs to be discussed directly (i.e. no online sign-up).

name: kunthar
text: yes

name: kunthar
text: also we have bintray. They have 1GB package size limit.

name: kunthar
text: also, we can provide 1 developer with 15 hours a week. we can help with CI&CD setup, automation parts.

name: peterclark
text: Messaged <http://packagecloud.io|packagecloud.io>,

name: kunthar
text: also for anyone wondering, we are not planning to commercially support Riak in future.

name: peterclark
text: As a community, no. As a company - I certainly am ^_^

name: kunthar
text: yes yes :slightly_smiling_face:

name: peterclark
text: We should probably start with even more basic questions:

name: kunthar
text: we will not give a support as a company :slightly_smiling_face:

name: peterclark
text:
- What rules will the community operate under? E.g. Apache
- What are it's aims? E.g. Manage source code, documentation, overall direction of the project (new features), build process, installation package management.
- Where should we be formed legally? E.g. UK

Once we agree on those, we can then move on to how to do the project aims.

name: peterclark
text:
If Apache, their Incubator information is here: <http://incubator.apache.org/>
What other open source Project frameworks can people recommend?

name: kunthar
text: we should have more info about legal issues.

name: peterclark
text: Yes.

name: kunthar
text: anyone?

name: peterclark
text: ESL has experience with this, and they already suggested the Apache Foundation to me.

name: peterclark
text: (ESL is Erlang Solutions Limited, in the UK)

name: heinz
text: Isn’t apache where projects go to die? I know that’s a bit of a cynical view but they impose a lot of ‘management’ which I’m not sure we really need.

name: heinz
text: To location the UK seems to be a icky place given brexit, we all don’t know how international trade w/ the UK will look in a year or two, ireland might be an alternative?

name: peterclark
text: That's a good point re the UK.

name: peterclark
text: Having said that, not sure it will matter that much for something like this.

name: heinz

name: peterclark
text: Erlang, Bet365 are in the UK, and TI Tokyo (me) has a presence there, too.

name: peterclark
text: I would imagine their support would out-weigh any other issues. Plus, we can always move :slightly_smiling_face:

name: heinz
text: oh yea I’ve no outright objections to the UK, just want to make sure we think about the possible consequences :wink:

name: sargun

name: sargun
text: <@U6RPFG5FH>, <@U6Q92JWHY> So, my experiences with the ASF have been that their processes sometimes make moving forward difficult. For example, in Mesos, when we wanted to add a new binary platform, it required a vote to ratify this. For a small team, that all worked at the same org, this wasn't very valuable.

name: sargun
text: With C*, it was similar, but votes, or meetings were called for other things that could have been more easily done without requiring a community vote.

name: heinz
text: sargun I share your concern

name: peterclark
text: We're going to be very distributed. Already in this Slack we have Japan, UK, Germany, USA. A bit of organisation is needed :slightly_smiling_face:

name: peterclark
text: Of course, going overboard is to be avoided.

name: peterclark
text: That is why I want to get as much agreed at the start as possible.

name: sargun
text: Basically, it's great until one organization tries to pull ahead of the others

name: heinz
text: there will be a lot of organisation needed but too much of it can be as harmful (or worse?) then too little

name: kunthar
text: "a bit of organization" needed

name: sargun

name: kunthar

name: sargun

name: peterclark
text: If we are getting funding (from companies like me, Erlang, Bet365, the NHS) we are going to need some of that.

name: sargun

name: sargun

name: peterclark
text: The ASF framework gives us that credibility from the get-go.

name: sargun
text: CNCF?

name: heinz
text: CNCF == Cloud Native?

name: sargun
text: yeah

name: heinz
text: Sorry I’ve not caught up with all the acronymes yet :slightly_smiling_face:

name: sargun
text: Any idea if Riak would have to become an incubating project

name: peterclark
text: For ASF? I think we can use their framework without joining, but we'd lose the credibility of being part of a larger group.

name: gpad
text: I think that we are talking of 2 different thing we could be under the umbrella of ASF or CNCF and another topic is the process that we adopt

name: heinz
text: I would hope that ESL, Erlang, Bet and it tokio would think riak is credible one way or another

name: gpad
text: An alternative framework is <https://rfc.zeromq.org/spec:42/C4/>

name: peterclark
text: Haha!

name: peterclark
text: Yes - but would the NHS invest money in a project without some kind of money management process?

name: heinz
text: I can see that, hence why I left them out of the list :stuck_out_tongue:

name: peterclark
text: :slightly_smiling_face:

name: peterclark
text: CNCF looks good, but the requirements for entry are pretty steep. It includes a 20 minute slide presentation at a committee meeting. No idea if that is in person or online.

name: peterclark
text: We also need a committee member to sponsor us.

name: heinz
text: CNCF feels like a bit less byrocracy

name: peterclark
text: They basically provide resources (hosting, etc...) and let you run the project however you want. Of course, they also only provide the resources if they approve of how you run the project!

name: heinz
text: My main worry with a large foundation is that it will hurt individual contributions, larger companies will have a easier time but John and Jenny who are excited and add a little thing here and there will most likely get scared of by lots of process and procedure.

name: heinz
text: My thought is mainly that a lighter process, will encourage a wider more diverse set of contributors instead of mostly companies contributing. Now I don’t know what’s right or wrong as an approach but to me that feels more appealing.

name: nadams
text:
Although developers are the lifeblood behind projects like this, might be worth thinking about the end users. Commercially, I have a use for Riak - as a solid, reliable, well coded key value store that will tolerate a fair amount of failure without losing data even though it does require a handful of servers to run successfully. As a private individual, I have next to no use for something like this in my home. I do not have hordes of servers nor do I have terabytes of data that must be live 24/7.

From the above, I would guess that corporate would be our customer target and as such we need enough organisation (rules and rigmarole) in place to look and sound professional.

As a coder, for stuff I do at home, I like to tinker with stuff and am ok when I have to spend a few hours trying to debug a random race condition caused by a hiccup 5 commits ago because the trigger factor is rare. For stuff at work, I'd think about switching to a better coded platform.

name: heinz
text: That is however less a community project and more a foundation

name: heinz
text: It is very little different then how basho ran riak towards the end just with a new flag

name: kunthar
text: catching the writings now, there should be a balance between power and coding. we should have an eco system and we should carefully think about what is the aim of involving parties. to me, there shouldn't be any rank to manage things from upstairs. i'd like to see a flat organization as much as possible.

name: heinz
text: kunthar agreed balancing things is going to be the hardest part I think, not only on power vs coding but also on accessability (to contribute) and quality.

name: kunthar
text: also, there are several different multi dimensional layers we should take in to account; 1. as my company does, we are consumers of riak goodness, on the other hand 2. there are high level developers enhancing the codebase. 3. on the other side there are professional companies giving support to other professional companies. 4. there are *legal issues which we are not aware yet*, how to affect our efforts.  5. we are going to need "some" resources and i believe this is the most basic part of this puzzle. my final words; i want high level devs continue to code in peace without any interruption. i am ready to take the low level duties to carry on the work. i do not want to see any kind of authority trying to bend our efforts for it's own benefit.

name: kunthar
text: it would be great if someone else enlighten us about these legal issues with basho. i mean what about ownership of the code? what happens if we use the TM names of basho, riak, etc.?

name: heinz
text: I got no idea

name: heinz
text: I think forking riak is fine fiven it’s under the APL and no one can take that “Back” for existing code but what do they tend to say IANAL

name: heinz
text: Donating the code to the ASF I imagine would be legally a lot more difficult as basho ‘owns’ it and I don’t see how we can domante something we don’t own

name: deadzen
text: Hello

name: kunthar
text: hello deadzen

name: deadzen
text: how goes it

name: kunthar
text: trying to figure out how things is divided and will be, in this concurrent, but monolithic single minded profit world.

name: mranney
text: <@U6RHSFM4Y|mranney> has joined the channel

name: peterclark
text: <@U6Q6G7S82> - no, we can't donate the Enterprise Edition code as none of us own it. Even distributing it is illegal. The current owners are selling it as we speak, so we just have to wait to find out what is going on with that. The open source code is free for anyone to use and modify, and that is the only thing we can use for this project unless the new owners of the Enterprise Edition code make it open source.

name: peterclark
text: <@U6PHKFTA5> There does need to be a central authority for approving changes or Riak will fragment. Changes outside of that authority can, and will, happen, but there needs to be a single official version for companies to risk spending a considerable amount of time and resources in implementing Riak - and without the support of companies this project will die. As <@U6QC6EQH2> said, this is not a home-use project!

name: peterclark
text:
In this case, I think we need the following groups:

- Development Group
- Code Approval Group
- Project Direction Group
- Admin Group

Their functions would be

Development Group
*What*: actually write code/scripts/tests. 
*Who*: open to anyone
*Support*: the central support services provided by the Admin Group.
 Sanity checks of the results would be provided by the Code Approval Group. The list of features would be provided by the Project Direction Group.
*Notes*: anyone can work on their own forks before saying to the Code Approval Group "I've got someone good I want to include". They would deal with bug fixes, and how new features are implemented.

Code Approval Group
*What*: approves code merges into the 'official' versions.
*Who*: a small group (5-10 max) of high-level developers.
*Support*: the central support services provided by the Admin Group.
 Overall guidance of what the features need to accomplish would be provided by the Project Direction Group. All submitted code would come from the Development Group.
*Notes*: They check the bug fixes/features meet the code quality standards and do what they are intended to do. They manage the code in GitHub and the creation of new builds. They can add any feature/fix they want to the official releases so long as it's quality meets their requirements.



Project Direction Group
*What*: defines what new features are desired/wanted.
*Who*: this would have technical reps developers and the companies using Riak. 
*Support*: the central support services provided by the Admin Group.
*Notes*: They would be the ones to say "we really need a multi-datacentre replication solution for Riak". Anyone from anywhere can suggest a new feature to them, join in the discussions, etc... Features would be prioritised for the Development Group to deal with, but if someone wants to develop a low-priority feature there should be nothing to stop that.


Admin Group 
*What*: handles the admin side of things, and provides common resources for other groups.
*Who*: anyone who wants to.
*Support*: information from the other Groups.
*Notes*: They would deal with things like donations, resources, sponsors, project promotion, etc. This would include things like Riak promotion material, public websites, ensuring payments for things occurred, managing the money, and anything else required for the other Groups to work. They would provide a group of central support services (like Slack, GitHub, mailing lists, documentation).

name: peterclark
text: Thoughts?

name: nadams
text: that sounds surprisingly logical! I could live with a setup like that. Only question would be how do we approve "high level developers"?

name: kunthar
text: we are not using Riak at our homes too. i have to say that,  i am not against bsd style commitee to manage technical aspects and centrally redirect duties.

name: kunthar
text: while i was writing <@U6Q92JWHY> came up with a good plan :slightly_smiling_face:

name: peterclark
text: :slightly_smiling_face:

name: peterclark
text: <@U6QC6EQH2> - good question. I'd imagine that we'd start with a group developers who say here "hey, I can help with that" and see how it goes. I'd imagine that we'd have to come up with some method of removing or adding people, but I'd hope most that would be done by the Groups internally.

name: peterclark
text: I.e. developers picking developers.

name: nadams
text: fair enough

name: peterclark
text: I'd imagine a vote of the Developers Group members to choose Code Approval members.

name: kunthar
text: we can discuss about base separation of duties. but generally this setup is fair enough. we should have a major principle that everyone should act equally as much as possible.

name: kunthar
text: <https://www.freebsd.org/administration.html>

name: kunthar
text: we could inspire of them?

name: peterclark
text: Handy link!

name: peterclark
text: I'll have a read.

name: kunthar
text: of course they are managing a quite huge OS project. lots of departments are useless for us.

name: peterclark
text: Yes - I'd imagine that we'd merge a lot of those listed!

name: kunthar
text: i am still thinking about admin group should be divided to small,  one duty clans like "donations team" etc.

name: kunthar
text: vendor relations for example is a very good idea :slightly_smiling_face: i believe esl and you would handle this <@U6Q92JWHY>?

name: peterclark
text: I think a lot of their services would go hand-in-hand. Some, like donations, money management and spending, are clearly linked. Same with promotion and public websites. And again for more technical things like managing common servers and services.

name: kunthar
text: this is what i imagine actually. getting an exact picture of the work and divide to manage effectively.

name: peterclark
text: ESL did a really good job of taking our (TI Tokyo) Riak Support material and making it look really nice.

name: peterclark
text: They are also very active in Erlang, and have a great sales team to promote Riak.

name: peterclark
text: I've invited them to join this Slack, and there is already one member here.

name: kunthar
text: i am wondering is there anyone in contact with the first engineering team of basho. For example Justin Sheehy.

name: peterclark
text: Probably!

name: kunthar
text: it would be great to see people, whom they had to quit the code because of some reason. i believe they would add great value to Riak itself. correct me if am wrong.

name: peterclark
text: Nope - very much spot on.

name: peterclark
text:
As a more-broken-down list of Groups, how's this:

- Development Group
    - Riak Core
    - Riak KV
    - Riak CS
    - Riak TS
    - Riak Client Tools
- Release Management Group
    - Code Approval Group
    - Testing Group
    - Build Group
- Project Direction Group
- Admin Group
    - Company Engagement Group (Riak promotion, public websites, etc...)
    - Finance Group (Handling donations, payments, subscriptions, etc...)
    - Services Group (running common services like FTP, web, CI/CD servers, email and mailing list provision, etc...)

name: peterclark
text: I split Code Approval Group up into their functions and grouped them under Release Management.

name: kunthar
text: good work. i have to leave for daily work now. i feel we have a good starting point.

name: peterclark
text: Yup - I hope to have an actual recommendation for the planning meeting!

name: peterclark
text: It will then, of course, be torn apart - but hopefully into something better :slightly_smiling_face:

name: kunthar
text: have a nice day/night to everyone :spock-hand:

name: peterclark
text: You, too!

name: nadams
text: have a good one

name: danabr
text: <@U6S21QLH3|danabr> has joined the channel

name: heinz
text: I think that plan will quite effectively kill any kind of community involvement beyond big companies it quite literally sounds like basho was running things towards the end just with a new name

name: heinz
text: `Project Direction Group` pretty much translates to “buy your way into directing where the development goes”, the riak is as good as it is because in the beginning a lot of decisions were made by engineers wanting to build something good not marketing or marketing reps

name: heinz
text: I am extremely critical of the direction of things discussed here, and the “but then no one will pay for things” feels a lot like trying to strong arm  things through at the threat of withholding support.

name: peterclark
text: Which is why a) it includes techies as well as end-users, b) they organise and prioritise, not stop forks, c) developers can ignore the prioritisation and work on things they want.

name: peterclark
text: It allows for companies to have their voices heard when they help pay for things, but allows developers freedom to chase their ideas.

name: peterclark
text: Final decisions on what is included is in the hands of the Code Approval Group which is made up of and chosen by developers.

name: heinz
text: peterclark thank you for clarifying those points, that sounds a lot less worrysome then what I understood from the first suggestion

name: peterclark
text: Async messages can be confusing :)

name: heinz
text: indeed

name: peterclark
text: I'll write up a better phrased version :)

name: heinz
text: also please don’t take my criticism personal, I tend to be up front about concerns as I belive not addressing them just leads to misery and well miscommunication in the long run :wink:

name: peterclark
text: Totally agree!

name: russelldb
text: ultimately code wins, as Vinoski used to say. And deployed code doubly so. I think having a plan for organisation is a great thing. Representing customers' wants was something Basho failed at pretty badly and it would be good to redress that

name: russelldb
text: bet365 have a full time riak team, and the NHS are moving that way. You don't think that those engineers are deciding the features they implement or bugs they fix, do you?

name: peterclark
text: That is why I put the end-users on the Project Direction Group. They will also (hopefully) provide developers who will implement things as part of the Developers Group and the Code Approval Group.

name: peterclark
text: It allows for developer led features as well as end-user led features. End-users who provide developers can direct their developers to work on the features they want, of course.

name: russelldb
text: my concern is that there isn't a single overarching design principle or goal. A lot of basho's earlier success came from a pretty clear shared goal on what Riak should be. And so decision making at all levels could be guided by that. As an engineer if I had to pick between implementation X or Y I could cast the decision through that lens and make an informed choice.

name: russelldb
text: Part of the NuBasho disaster was trying to be all things to all deployments, rather than focussing on Riak's niche (this is just my opinion obviously)

name: peterclark
text: How would you suggest fixing that?

name: russelldb
text: talking, finding out what everyone thinks the goal is

name: russelldb
text: I think your organisation idea sounds like it can facilitate that

name: russelldb
text: we're lucky at the NHS in that they have a very clear idea of what they want from Riak, and thanks to their experience are able to articulate it too

name: russelldb
text: it would be great if every interested organisation could take the time to think that through up front

name: peterclark
text: For sure!

name: peterclark
text: Sounds like a dream client!

name: deadzen
text: vinoski wisdoms are great :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye:, agreed has anyone reviewed global logical clocks applied to riak?

name: russelldb
text: <@U6S4RDVEE> a little, CMJ and I went to Braga in (I think) 2014 and got a 1st hand preso from Tomé on GLC. I haven't read the latest paper, but we always had issues with 2 things, one syncing the global counter per write ('cos gaps _mean_ something so leasing was not an option iirc)

name: russelldb
text: second was about absence of dots meaning deletes. If you spread the dots over many keys and a corruption means you can't read key X then it looks like a legit delete and propagates around the cluster

name: russelldb
text: the latest paper may address both those concerns (it's on my queue)

name: deadzen
text: cool, i had a discussion with him in 2016, about server wide clocks, what I found very interesting (not that it directly applied to riak core as it assumes the presence of a kv)  was that it did replica repair instead of using AAE with merkle trees.. there was a dotteddb proof of concept and a basicdb (with aae/merkle) to do a fair benchmark against..

name: deadzen
text: he added, SWC is a bit more complicated, adds state to vnodes and so on.. but that it could be integrated, depending on what purpose you wanted riak core to serve

name: deadzen
text: <@U6S4RDVEE|deadzen> set the channel topic: “In preparing for battle I have always found that plans are useless, but planning is indispenable.” —Dwight D. Eisenhower
topic: “In preparing for battle I have always found that plans are useless, but planning is indispenable.” —Dwight D. Eisenhower

name: russelldb
text: <@U6S4RDVEE> we had a look at the dot based AAE, it's not so simple, involves an in memory reverse key->dot index iirc

name: russelldb
text: in general my view (until I read the new paper) is that it is very interesting but has some implementation problems to be overcome before it is industry ready

name: meangrape
text: <@U6SLDDGKC|meangrape> has joined the channel

name: russelldb
text: I think <@U6Q3DV4FM>' AAE work is more promising and general

name: deadzen
text: if AAE can be made to be much lighter than it is, than sure. I'll have to brush up on that work myself, if the problem that AAE solves can be prevented from happening in the read repair. that would be a cool thing.

name: russelldb
text: you can't prevent the need for AAE imo

name: peterclark
text: I took Gordon's one, my one and the feedback from people here.

name: deadzen
text: no doubt

name: peterclark
text: I fully expect this to get torn to shred's, by the way.

name: deadzen
text: I like your confidence, I am the kind to shred things down to 4-5 things

name: peterclark
text: Well, the idea is for the best idea to win :slightly_smiling_face:

name: peterclark
text: In this, I have no ego, fear not!

name: deadzen
text: let's start with that, what is the idea?

name: peterclark
text:
Well:

```6.	Aims
The aim of this project is to provide:
	A canonical open source version of source code for Riak.
	Tested installation packages of Riak for supported OSs.
	Canonical documentation on how to use Riak.
	Product information on when and why to use Riak.
	A public and easily understood minimalist structure. 
```

name: peterclark
text: This document is more how I think we should go about the project, not the details of what should be built.

name: peterclark
text: I tend to go with Bill & Ted: "Be excellent to each other. And, party on, dude."

name: peterclark
text: Anyone who wants to introduce themselves, go ahead now.

name: deadzen
text: customary that you start :wink:

name: peterclark
text: I'm Peter Clark, of TI Tokyo in Japan. My company provides enterprise-grade worldwide support to Riak end-users.

name: peterclark
text: The nice thing about text is that we can all type at once for common questions like that.

name: mrallen1

name: mrallen1
text: We use Riak rather extensively

name: sjmw
text: I'm Stuart Whitfield, Erlang Solutions CEO. We do anything and everything connected to the Erlang ecosystem. We've been a Risk reseller/support provider/consultancy from the early days

name: binarytemple

name: russelldb

name: sjmw
text: I'd also like to identify and contact the major enterprise users who, arguably, have the biggest commercial interest in this project and contact them to ensure active participation (or a firm 'no, we don't want to participate'). We know who they are and now we have at least some more certainty re IPR we can contact them all. Getting them on board now will mean a better outcome and potentially greater resources to ensure the community can deliver on its plans for Riak. This will be an OSS project but will need some commercial funding too

name: peterclark
text: The idea is that the Project Direction Group says "we want XYZ". The Developers figure out how, and the Release Management Group sanity check it and make a release.

name: peterclark
text: If a Developer wanted a new backend, just propose it to the Project Direction Group and it goes in the stack of things to get built.

name: russelldb
text: <@U6Q92JWHY> often developers 80% make things first, and then it would go to product to decide if needs finishing, but I get your meaning

name: peterclark

name: heinz

name: peterclark

name: peterclark
text: We should add in something to review that, true.

name: heinz
text: yes it should be clearly governed however

name: peterclark
text: Maybe get the Governance Group to OK them?

name: heinz
text: Sounds good to me

name: peterclark
text: In which case the Project Direction Group essentially has two hats.

name: heinz
text: It just feels good to have a saveguard against crazy

name: peterclark
text: So we split them as Stuart(?) suggested.

name: steve_erlang
text: There's always a trade off between strict governance to create a single version and encouraging innovation/flexiblity. If governance is too restrictive then Riak will fragment/fork.

name: peterclark
text: Yes. I'd have Governance as part of the Admin Group, and chosen by the Project Direction Group.

name: peterclark
text: Governance would then do the safety checks.

name: peterclark
text: I.e. Project Direction Group is the board, Governance is the executive.

name: heinz
text: It probably doesn’t matter for most small stuff, but just someone doing a sanity check, on “yes we want that company/group as part of our directional board” makes sense, every other office is elected so we get that checks there automatically.

name: deadzen
text: <@U6Q92JWHY> has a layout like this been used before with any other groups?

name: peterclark
text:
Inserting:
```9.4.3.	Governance Team
In charge of:
	Executing the vision laid down by the Project Direction Group.
	Co-ordinating between Groups and Teams.
```

name: peterclark
text: <@U6S4RDVEE> - no idea. I just went with what I thought was best.

name: peterclark
text: I did read up on a few others but most of them seems to have a lot more overhead.

name: heinz
text: I think it’s good to start off with little overhead, it’s always easy to grow more complex but very hard to simplify

name: peterclark
text: Also easy to grow wrong :slightly_smiling_face:

name: deadzen
text: I've been researching a lot into management cybernetics, theres some valuable insight on reducing oscillation between groups and teams..  This is not a new problem by any means

name: peterclark
text: ```	Checks new build works as expected.```

name: peterclark
text:
So:

```9.2.10.	Build Team
	Receive work packet from Documentation Team.
	Creates build process.
	Checks new build works as expected.
	Either releases new version to the public, or returns to the Development Group team for fixes.
```

name: heinz
text: so reading through it all in all I think it’s a really great starting point

name: steve_erlang
text: When Basho was alive - the direction / roadmap was a result of customers buying the product and influencing the roadmap. This is being market driven demand is being lost. If a company funds the development of a feature (either publicly or privately) then I guess it should by default be included in the Product Direction.

name: heinz
text: How would changes to the process happen? Say we just took this today, how weould we go about changing something we found worked or didn’t work

name: deadzen
text: the membership management seems a little lottery/game theory to me

name: heinz
text: I think not nessessariy, some features might come with an incredibly high maintainaince/longterm overhead which we might not want to carry just because someone initially sponsored it.

name: peterclark
text: As I see it, they would propose a new feature, the PDG would discuss how (or if) it fits with Riak. If they decide it doesn't it either gets added as low priority or it happens in a company-specific fork.

name: russelldb
text: That sounds like most of the basho added features tbf. It's best if we don't think of Riak as a good template imo

name: peterclark
text: We would have to have a review process in place going to Governance, which then got voted on by the relevant Team or Group or everyone.

name: deadzen
text: I have experience with riak_test

name: heinz
text: Yap, something along the lines. Review process should be part of the charter (I call it that  now :P) so it ‘protects itself’ in a way.

name: peterclark
text: I imagine that it will take some refining to get it going smoothly.

name: peterclark
text: Handy!

name: peterclark
text: Makes sense.

name: peterclark
text: That will go in the next revision!

name: deadzen

name: mrallen1
text: I mean... I can't ever remember an outside contribution coming into to riak_kv or core that wasn't from someone already deep into Basho (either current or former) so my expectation is that people who are funding specific development are going to be working with a consultant (like <@U6R6ETJU8> probably) to do that sort of thing and they're going to be maintaining some kind of "internal" facing fork and contributing back to larger project periodically

name: heinz
text: We might also want to schedule a fixed review time ahead of time that forces us to consider if things work. At least for the first year or so that we’re not growing complacent and just accept it because calling for a get together is so much work.

name: peterclark
text:
From the PDG it will be fairly high level ("make replication work between datacenters".
The Developers would then break it down into smaller parts.

text: <@U6R6ETJU8> ttyl

name: steve_erlang
text: I think a key thing is some guiding principles for product direction.  Riak started off aiming to be bullet proof and do something well. It's lost direction over time and things which were probably a good idea but half baked ended up being released (eg Yokuzuna).  There are plenty of companies using Riak because it's a mission critical application - I think we need to get back to basics and do things well. So document needs a "mission statement" I suppose for Riak direction.

text: One question - forgive if tangential - Elixir. It's a long term question but I'd the future of Riak always going to be Erlang?

name: heinz
text: Please yes as using erlang code from elixir is easy, using elixir code from erlang is hard.

name: heinz
text: At least for anything that is even remotely a library we should stick with pure erlang

name: gpad
text: I wrote some posts of how to use riak_core from elixir thanks to <@U6Q6G7S82>

name: peterclark
text: Sounds like something to discuss. I would imagine that moving language would involve a LOT of discussion!

name: peterclark
text: Unless the reasons were freakin' awesome, I'd lean towards sticking with Erlang.

name: heinz
text: Okay let me be clear what I mean, making riak (and all it’s libs) work on elixir  is something we should do. But if we start writing things in elixir we exclude any erlang applications from using them.
